sent_inference: I enjoy going sailing with my father.
I don't like eating out at upscale places.
Two of the shirts were striped.
Some of the movies were funny.
The player was skillful or hardworking.
sent_manipulation: Bob spends a lot of time with his family.
John has no interest in fashion or clothes.
Bob cares about his students and keeps in touch with them.
Bob typically goes to sleep in movies.
Bob watches the weather channel every day.
Bob goes to the bakery every day.
Bob has only seen one or two football games.
sent_context: John and Bob were talking about sailing yesterday.
John and Bob were talking about restaurants yesterday.
Last month, Bob and John were talking about the selection of shirts at a local store.
A year ago, Bob and John were talking about the students in a class they taught.
Yesterday, John and Bob were talking about the movies at a local theater.
Bob and John were talking about the weather during the previous weekend.
A few days ago, John and Bob were talking about a particular kind of cookie at a local bakery.
Last week, John and Bob were talking about a player in a recent football game.
expt_aim: test if people interpret certain words or phrases as having exclusionary meanings
sent_question: he enjoys walking in the woods alone?
two but not three of the shirts were striped?
the students were not always tired?
not all of the movies were funny?
he did not love the cookie?
the player was not both skillful and hardworking?
